title: 21-Years-Owned 2001 Ferrari 360 Spider
description: This 2001 Ferrari 360 Spider was first delivered to Midwestern Auto Group in Dublin, Ohio, and it was purchased by its current owner in July 2003. Equipment includes a Capristo exhaust system, 18" five-spoke alloy wheels, a black convertible soft top, a Challenge-style rear grille, xenon headlights, power-adjustable Daytona-style seats, and automatic climate control. This 360 Spider is now offered on dealer consignment with a window sticker, the owner's manual, a car cover, steering wheel and seat covers, a tire repair kit, tools, a clean Carfax report, and a clean California title.

The Pininfarina-designed aluminum body is finished in Rosso Corsa and features xenon headlights, a power-retractable black convertible soft top, a Challenge-style rear grille, fender badges, and quad exhaust outlets exiting through the rear fascia.

The 18″ five-spoke alloy wheels show curb marks and are mounted with Bridgestone Potenza tires, which were reportedly fitted about two years ago. Stopping power is from red-finished Ferrari-branded calipers over cross-drilled and ventilated rotors at each corner.

The cockpit features power-adjustable Daytona-style seats upholstered in beige leather with black accents along with matching door panel inserts and carpets. Amenities include aluminum pedals, a CD stereo, and automatic climate control. Photos showing wear on the interior surfaces are included in the gallery.

The leather-wrapped steering wheel frames a 220-mph speedometer and a tachometer with an 8,500-rpm redline as well as a digital fuel level readout and gauges for oil pressure, oil temperature, and coolant temperature. The mid-mounted 3.6-liter Tipo F131 V8 features a flat-plane crankshaft, dry-sump lubrication, dual overhead camshafts, and five valves per cylinder. Factory-rated output was 395 horsepower and 275 lb-ft of torque. A Capristo exhaust system has been added. A belt service was most recently carried out in October 2020.

Power is sent to the rear wheels through an electrohydraulic six-speed F1 sequential transaxle and a limited-slip differential. The clutch is said to have been replaced about three years ago.

The Carfax report is free from accidents or other reported damage.
